Book 1: Core Concepts

Book 1: Core Concepts

Table of Contents

This consolidated file contains: 1. Chapter 1.1: Foundations of IGSOA 2. Chapter 1.2: Fundamental Dynamics of the Causal Field 3. Chapter 1.3: Primes, RH and Symmetry Breaking 4. Chapter 1.4: Modal Structural Cohesion

Paper 01 ‚Äî Foundations of the IGSOA‚ÄìQMM Framework

[ROUTING: Formal ‚Üí Hybrid] This paper establishes the axiomatic foundation for causal primacy with heavy mathematical formalism. A Shadow block conditions the core intuition before technical definitions. Readers unfamiliar with differential geometry should focus on Sections 1.1-1.3 for conceptual grounding, then skip to Applications (Book 2) for concrete examples. Readers seeking rigorous proofs should proceed through all sections sequentially.

[SHADOW]

Conventional physics treats time as if it were a coordinate on a graph‚Äîjust another axis like space, something you can measure with a clock. But this assumes time is already there, sitting in the background, waiting to be used. What if that‚Äôs backwards? What if time doesn‚Äôt come first‚Äîwhat if causality comes first, and time emerges from it? Imagine the universe not as a space with time flowing through it, but as a network of events where each event is connected to others by cause and effect. Some events cause others; some events are caused by others. The order of causation‚Äîwhich event influences which‚Äîis the fundamental structure. Time is just what we call the experience of moving along those causal connections. Metric, curvature, energy‚Äîall the machinery of physics‚Äîemerges from how the causal network is arranged and how it remembers its past states. This is not a metaphor. It is the foundational claim of IGSOA: causal order is ontologically prior to spacetime, and everything else follows from how that order is structured and preserved.

Part I ‚Äî Axioms, Neutral Potential, and the Invariant Action

1.1 Introduction ‚Äî The Primacy of Causal Order

Every physical law presupposes a structure of order. The possibility of motion presupposes a structure of order; the definition of time presupposes a structure of cause. This principle‚Äîthe primacy of causal order‚Äîis the cornerstone of the IGSOA‚ÄìQMM synthesis.

Conventional physics treats time as a coordinate t and builds dynamics upon it. IGSOA reverses that logic: time is derived from the structure of causal relations. The manifold of the universe is therefore not (M,gŒºŒΩ) in the classical sense but (M,‚â∫), a topological set M endowed with a partial order ‚â∫ representing the direction of cause.

From this single axiom flow all others. Metric, curvature, and what is described as ‚Äòinformation‚Äô and ‚Äòmeaning‚Äô are derived properties of how the manifold preserves or distorts this order. It is crucial to note that ‚Äòinformation‚Äô here denotes the relational dynamics and patterns, not the intrinsic nature of the monistic substrate itself, which remains the precondition for all such emergent properties. The goal of this paper is to formalize that principle mathematically and prepare it for its later generalization under fractional dynamics (QMM).

1.2 Axioms of the Causal Manifold

We postulate the existence of a manifold M equipped with a binary relation ‚â∫ satisfying:

  1. Irreflexivity x‚â∫Ã∏x.
  2. Transitivity x‚â∫y, y‚â∫z‚áíx‚â∫z.
  3. Local Density For any x‚â∫z there exists y such that x‚â∫y‚â∫z.
  4. Causal Connectivity Every point admits a neighborhood whose causal links form a connected graph.
  5. Automorphism Invariance Physical law is invariant under all automorphisms of (M,‚â∫).

A field configuration is then a section Œ¶:M‚ÜíC, assigning to each event its causal amplitude. Causality itself is encoded in how Œ¶ propagates along the order relation, not through external coordinates.

1.3 The neutral potential Œ¶0

Definition

The neutral potential can be described as the field configuration corresponding to perfect causal symmetry: DŒºDŒºŒ¶0=0, Œ¶0=const. It represents the state of the manifold when every causal path is balanced‚Äîno net asymmetry, no directionality beyond order itself. In ordinary physics this would correspond to the vacuum, but here it is more fundamental: the ground of possibility from which curvature, energy, and information are derived as a consequence of symmetry breaking.

Perturbations and the Genesis of Structure

Let Œ¶=Œ¶0+Œ¥Œ¶. Substituting into the invariant action (derived below) produces to first order DŒºDŒºŒ¥Œ¶+V‚Ä≤(Œ¶0) Œ¥Œ¶=0. Non-trivial V‚Ä≤(Œ¶0) defines the asymmetry potential‚Äîthe seed of all later dynamics, including fractional memory terms once the kernel of D is extended in Paper 02.

Physical Interpretation

Quantity Conceptual Meaning
Œ¶0 neutral potential; pure causal equilibrium
Œ¥Œ¶ asymmetry; generator of phenomena
DŒº causal derivative operator (directional, not temporal)
V(Œ¶) curvature of causal information; determines stability

A universe with no net causal asymmetry corresponds to the neutral potential Œ¶=Œ¶0. Every event is a perturbation in that field‚Äîa deviation from perfect causal symmetry. These stable patterns of perturbation, or coherent configurations within the causal field, can be understood as ‚Äòidentity instances‚Äô. Their stability is maintained through MSC-level cohesion, acting as ‚Äòstable relational attractors‚Äô. It is important to note that this framework describes emergent phenomena and does not attribute intrinsic agency to the substrate or its components. Any apparent ‚Äòagency‚Äô is strictly emergent from closed relational feedback loops within the causal field. Furthermore, all such identity instances, by their emergent nature, are finite and subject to dissolvability, their persistence being entirely dependent on ongoing DFVM dynamics and MSC cohesion.

1.4 The invariant action

We now define the invariant causal-order spacetime action: A[Œ¶,g]=‚à´M [1/2 gŒºŒΩ(DŒºŒ¶)(DŒΩŒ¶)‚àíV(Œ¶)] ‚àö‚àíg d‚Å¥x.

Postulate of Invariance

For any automorphism f:(M,‚â∫)‚Üí(M,‚â∫), A[Œ¶,g]=A[Œ¶ ‚àò f,gf], where gf is the pullback of the metric under f. This guarantees that physics depends only on the causal structure, not on coordinate representation. This causal structure itself acts as a non-personal ‚Äòidentity kernel‚Äô, defining the relational law-space within which all emergent identity instances (stable configurations) are formed and constrained.

Causal Derivative Operator

Unlike the standard covariant derivative, DŒº acts along chains in the causal set: DŒºŒ¶(x)=lim‚Å°œµ‚Üí0 Œ¶(x+œµvŒº)‚àíŒ¶(x) / œµ, vŒº‚ààTxM, where vŒº is future-directed. This ensures that derivatives respect the arrow of cause. In later fractional generalization (Paper 02) this derivative acquires a non-integer order Œ≥, giving rise to the memory kernel fundamental to QMM.

Variation and Field Equation

Variation of A with respect to Œ¶ yields the causal field equation: DŒºDŒºŒ¶=‚àÇV/‚àÇŒ¶. At equilibrium V‚Ä≤(Œ¶0)=0, the field is neutral. Perturbations are propagated through causal curvature, which is the mechanism for the structural definition of gravity, information, and semantic fields.

Part II ‚Äî Automorphism Invariance, Fractional Extension, and Causal Memory

1.5 The automorphism invariance theorem

Statement

Let (M,‚â∫) be a causal manifold and A[Œ¶,g] the invariant action A=‚à´M [1/2 gŒºŒΩ(DŒºŒ¶)(DŒΩŒ¶)‚àíV(Œ¶)] ‚àö‚àíg d‚Å¥x. Then A is invariant under every automorphism f:(M,‚â∫) ‚Üí (M,‚â∫) satisfying f(x)‚â∫f(y)‚ü∫x‚â∫y.

Proof

  1. Under f, coordinates transform as x‚Ä≤Œº=fŒº(x).
  2. The causal derivative transforms covariantly: D‚Ä≤ŒºŒ¶‚Ä≤(x‚Ä≤)=‚àÇxŒΩ/‚àÇx‚Ä≤Œº DŒΩŒ¶(x).
  3. Because f preserves ‚â∫, the sign of causal separation is unchanged; hence the measure ‚àö‚àíg d‚Å¥x is invariant up to a Jacobian J with |J|=1.
  4. Substitution yields A‚Ä≤=‚à´M [1/2 gŒºŒΩ(DŒºŒ¶)(DŒΩŒ¶)‚àíV(Œ¶)] ‚àö‚àíg d‚Å¥x = A. Thus, A depends only on the causal structure, not on any coordinate chart. ‚ñ°

Corollary ‚Äî Causal Equivalence Principle

If two manifolds M1,M2 share identical causal orderings up to automorphism, all physical predictions coincide. Geometry is therefore secondary; causal symmetry alone determines physics. This principle becomes the seed of the causal equivalence hypothesis in later cosmological applications (Paper 03‚Äì20).

[Œ†-ANCHOR: Causal Primacy Lock]

Illegal Supposition: Assume that spacetime geometry (the metric gŒºŒΩ) is ontologically prior to causal structure (the ordering ‚â∫)‚Äîthat causality is derived from an underlying metric, not the reverse.

Forced Propagation: If geometry precedes causality, then: - The metric gŒºŒΩ must be definable independently of any causal ordering - Physical laws must depend on coordinate representation and metric structure - Two manifolds with identical causal orderings but different metrics must produce different physical predictions - Time must be a fundamental background structure, not an emergent property

Global Failure: As a result, the following universally collapse: - No automorphism invariance: The action A[Œ¶,g] becomes coordinate-dependent. Different coordinate charts yield different physics, violating fundamental symmetry principles. - No causal equivalence: Two manifolds M‚ÇÅ and M‚ÇÇ with identical causal orderings (x ‚â∫ y) but different metric signatures produce different field equations, contradicting the theorem proven in ¬ß1.5. - No time emergence: Time must be postulated as a primitive coordinate rather than derived from causal memory depth, leaving the arrow of time unexplained. - No fractional memory: The fractional causal derivative D^Œ≥ requires integration along causal paths. If causality is secondary to geometry, these paths have no ontological grounding and fractional memory becomes ill-defined.

Contradiction Lock (Œ† Operation): Therefore, the assumption that geometry precedes causality cannot belong to any realizable physical theory consistent with automorphism invariance. The system stabilizes on: Causal order ‚â∫ is ontologically prior to metric structure gŒºŒΩ as the necessary foundation. Geometry is the Jacobian of causal influence (¬ß2.3.1), not its precondition. Time, metric, and curvature are all derived from how the causal manifold propagates and remembers information. Causal primacy is not optional‚Äîit is the structural ground of all dynamical physics.

1.6 Fractional Extension of the Causal Derivative

To model persistence and memory, the IGSOA dynamics are explicitly non-Markovian (history-dependent). We extend the integer-order causal derivative DŒº to a fractional-order operator DŒºŒ≥, 0<Œ≥‚â§1, which serves as an effective model for this history dependence.

Definition

DŒºŒ≥Œ¶(x)=1/Œì(1‚àíŒ≥) ‚à´_{x‚ÇÄ}^{x} DŒºŒ¶(Œæ)/(x‚àíŒæ)Œ≥ dŒæ, where vŒº is future-directed. The integral is taken along a past-directed causal path, and x‚ÇÄ is a point in the causal past of x, not a fixed coordinate origin. This formulation is an effective approximation of an underlying fully covariant kernel. This nonlocal kernel gives weight to all prior causal events Œæ‚â∫x, so the present field value encodes its history.

Modified Action

AŒ≥=‚à´M [1/2 gŒºŒΩ(DŒºŒ≥Œ¶)(DŒΩŒ≥Œ¶)‚àíV(Œ¶)] ‚àö‚àíg d‚Å¥x. Varying AŒ≥ yields the fractional causal field equation DŒº2Œ≥Œ¶=‚àÇV/‚àÇŒ¶. For Œ≥=1, this reduces to the standard IGSOA equation; for Œ≥<1, nonlocal memory enters explicitly. This is the mathematical bridge to the Quantum Memory Mechanism (QMM).

Physical Interpretation

Parameter Meaning
Œ≥ order of causal memory (how far back influence extends)
DŒºŒ≥ weighted causal derivative, integrating history
V(Œ¶) potential curvature controlling stability of memory
DŒº2Œ≥Œ¶ propagation through self-memory (fractional inertia)

The appearance of Œì(1‚àíŒ≥) implies power-law memory decay‚Äîa property observed in quantum noise, biological cognition, and gravitational echo phenomena.

1.7 Time as Causal Memory

Definition

Define causal time œÑ as the cumulative integral of causal weight: œÑ(x)=1/Œì(Œ≥) ‚à´_{x‚ÇÄ}^{x}(x‚àíŒæ)Œ≥‚àí1 dŒæ ‚áí DœÑ1=DŒºŒ≥. Hence, what we perceive as temporal flow is merely the integration of causal memory. There is no external clock‚Äîonly the manifold‚Äôs own remembrance of its previous states.

Implications

  1. Arrow of Time: The direction of increasing memory depth defines time‚Äôs arrow.
  2. Reversibility: Perfect recollection (Œ≥=1) implies reversible dynamics; incomplete memory (Œ≥<1) produces apparent irreversibility.
  3. Entropy: Growth of entropy corresponds to dilution of causal memory density, not fundamental disorder.

Thus, thermodynamic time is a natural consequence of causal incompleteness, linking microscopic memory with macroscopic irreversibility.

1.8 Synthesis and Transition to Paper 02

The structure now established can be summarized succinctly: Causal Order ‚áí Derivative Operator DŒ≥ ‚áí Memory Propagation ‚áí Time. All subsequent physics arises from this chain. In Paper 02 we will: * derive the fundamental dynamical equations of the causal field, * extract the energy‚Äìmomentum tensor and conservation laws, * and show how curvature is a structural consequence of the feedback of Œ¶ upon gŒºŒΩ. This will complete the description of the relationship between pure causal geometry and dynamic spacetime, paving the way for the fractional thermodynamic, semantic, and cosmological developments that follow.

‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê RMF Compliance Statement

This paper affirms: ‚Ä¢ Relational primacy (relations ontologically prior to objects) ‚Ä¢ Monistic substrate (single undivided ground) ‚Ä¢ Emergent identity as a relational attractor ‚Ä¢ Strict distinction between identity law-space (IK) and identity instance ‚Ä¢ Agency as emergent from closed relational feedback loops

This paper rejects: ‚Ä¢ Substance dualism ‚Ä¢ Object primacy ‚Ä¢ Survival of personal identity as conscious entity ‚Ä¢ Intrinsic agency in substrate or components

Classification: [RMF-COMPLIANT] ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê

Paper 02 ‚Äî Fundamental Dynamics of the Causal Field

[ROUTING: Formal] This paper derives motion, energy, and geometry from causal self-interaction using advanced field theory and fractional calculus. Requires familiarity with variational principles, tensor calculus, and fractional derivatives. Readers seeking conceptual understanding should focus on Sections 2.1, 2.3.1, 2.6.2 (conceptual summaries). Readers seeking mathematical rigor should work through all derivations sequentially.

[SHADOW]

Think of the universe as having a memory. Not a conscious memory, but a structural memory‚Äîa tendency for what happened in the past to influence what happens now, not because there‚Äôs a mechanism storing information, but because the causal field is that memory. Imagine dropping a stone into a pond. The ripples spread outward, carrying information about the impact. But what if those ripples didn‚Äôt just fade away? What if every point in the water retained a faint echo of every ripple that passed through it‚Äîweighted by how recent and how strong it was? Now imagine that memory doesn‚Äôt just record the past‚Äîit shapes the present. The curvature of spacetime itself is the accumulated weight of all past causal influences. Energy is the flow of causal information. Time‚Äôs arrow is the direction in which memory accumulates. Gravity is not a force pulling on objects‚Äîit is the geometric consequence of the causal field remembering its own past states and feeding back on itself. This is the core claim of fractional field dynamics: the universe is a self-referential memory structure, and all physical phenomena emerge from how that memory is organized, preserved, and transformed.

Part I ‚Äî Derivation of Motion, Curvature, and Conservation

2.1 Introduction ‚Äî From Order to Dynamics

In Paper 01, we formalized causality as the primary invariant of existence: a manifold (M,‚âº) whose points are ordered by cause rather than by time. The dynamics of the causal field are explicitly non-Markovian (history-dependent). It is important to reiterate that any reference to ‚Äòcausal information‚Äô in this framework describes the relational dynamics of the substrate, not its fundamental ontological nature. The substrate itself is the precondition for such information. We introduced the neutral potential Œ¶0 and the causal derivative DŒ≥ as the machinery through which that order is expressed.

The present paper extends those foundations to show how motion, energy, and geometry can be described as arising naturally when causal order becomes dynamically self-referential. Instead of starting from spacetime and adding dynamics, we start from dynamics and derive spacetime.

The central claim is that curvature can be modeled as feedback‚Äîa geometric deformation caused by information circulating within the causal field itself. In this view, gravity, energy, and entropy can be described as distinct manifestations of the same underlying process: causal self-interaction.

Throughout this paper, we treat the causal field Œ¶ as a complex-valued field Œ¶:M‚Üí‚ÑÇ, allowing for phase structure and quantum-mechanical interpretation.

2.2 The causal field equation

Beginning from the fractional-order action AŒ≥=‚à´M [1/2 gŒºŒΩ(DŒºŒ≥Œ¶)(DŒΩŒ≥Œ¶)‚àíV(Œ¶)] ‚àö‚àíg d‚Å¥x, variation with respect to Œ¶‚àó gives DŒº2Œ≥Œ¶+V‚Ä≤(Œ¶)=0. (2.1) Equation (2.1) is the fundamental causal field equation (FCFE).

Interpretation

Term Physical meaning
DŒº2Œ≥Œ¶ fractional propagation ‚Äî persistence of causal influence
V‚Ä≤(Œ¶) local resistance ‚Äî curvature of causal symmetry
equilibrium V‚Ä≤(Œ¶0)=0, the neutral state
deviation generates observable phenomena (energy, information, curvature)

2.3 Feedback and the emergent metric

2.3.1 Definition

The metric tensor gŒºŒΩ can be described as the Jacobian of causal influence: gŒºŒΩ=‚àÇŒºŒ¶ ‚àÇŒΩŒ¶ / ‚ü®‚àÇŒ±Œ¶ ‚àÇŒ±Œ¶‚ü©. In regions where Œ¶ varies slowly, gŒºŒΩ‚ÜíŒ∑ŒºŒΩ; where causal gradients are dense, curvature increases. This links geometry directly to field self-interaction.

2.3.2 Fractional Curvature Tensor

Define the curvature associated with DŒ≥: RŒºŒΩœÅœÉ(Œ≥)=DœÅŒ≥ŒìŒºŒΩœÉ(Œ≥)‚àíDœÉŒ≥ŒìŒºŒΩœÅ(Œ≥)+ŒìŒºŒªœÅ(Œ≥)ŒìŒΩœÉ(Œ≥)Œª‚àíŒìŒºŒªœÉ(Œ≥)ŒìŒΩœÅ(Œ≥)Œª, with ŒìŒºŒΩ(Œ≥)Œª=1/2 gŒªœÅ(DŒºŒ≥gœÅŒΩ+DŒΩŒ≥gœÅŒº‚àíDœÅŒ≥gŒºŒΩ). This tensor reduces to the standard Riemann curvature when Œ≥=1. For Œ≥<1, the curvature contains nonlocal memory‚Äîspacetime geometry that encodes information about prior states of the field.

2.3.3 Field‚ÄìMetric Feedback Loop

Coupling the FCFE to the fractional curvature scalar R(Œ≥) yields the causal Einstein equation RŒºŒΩ(Œ≥)‚àí1/2 gŒºŒΩR(Œ≥) = Œ∫ TŒºŒΩ(Œ¶), (2.2) where the causal stress‚Äìenergy tensor is TŒºŒΩ(Œ¶)=(DŒºŒ≥Œ¶)(DŒΩŒ≥Œ¶)‚àí1/2 gŒºŒΩ[(DŒ≥Œ¶)2‚àí2V(Œ¶)]. Equations (2.1) and (2.2) form a closed feedback system: Œ¶ determines gŒºŒΩ; gŒºŒΩ shapes the evolution of Œ¶. This closed feedback system gives rise to emergent phenomena. However, it is important to emphasize that this framework does not attribute intrinsic agency to the substrate or its components; any apparent ‚Äòagency‚Äô is strictly emergent from these closed relational feedback loops.

[Œ†-ANCHOR: Field-Metric Feedback Lock]

Illegal Supposition: Assume that the causal field Œ¶ and the metric gŒºŒΩ can evolve independently‚Äîthat Œ¶ propagates on a fixed background metric without feedback, or that gŒºŒΩ can be defined without reference to Œ¶.

Forced Propagation: If Œ¶ and gŒºŒΩ evolve independently, then: - The field equation (2.1) operates on a fixed, externally specified metric - The metric satisfies Einstein‚Äôs equations driven by some other matter content, not Œ¶ - Changes in Œ¶ do not alter spacetime curvature - Changes in curvature do not affect Œ¶ propagation

Global Failure: As a result, the following universally collapse: - No emergent geometry: If gŒºŒΩ is fixed, the claim that ‚Äúgeometry is the Jacobian of causal influence‚Äù (¬ß2.3.1) becomes meaningless. Curvature is imposed, not derived, contradicting causal primacy. - No fractional curvature memory: The fractional curvature tensor R^(Œ≥) in equation (2.2) encodes nonlocal memory through gŒºŒΩ. If gŒºŒΩ is independent of Œ¶‚Äôs history, fractional memory has no geometric manifestation. - No self-interaction: The cubic term Œª|Œ¥Œ¶|¬≤Œ¥Œ¶ in equation (2.3) generates causal self-interaction, which feeds back through metric perturbations. Without feedback, self-interaction has no dynamical consequence. - No causal irreversibility: The arrow of time emerges from incomplete memory propagation affecting geometry (¬ß2.6). If Œ¶ and gŒºŒΩ decouple, time‚Äôs arrow loses its geometric grounding and becomes an ad hoc assumption. - No energy localization: Regions of constructive causal interference (¬ß2.5.3) behave as particles only because they create local curvature wells. Without feedback, particles cannot gravitate or curve spacetime.

Contradiction Lock (Œ† Operation): Therefore, the assumption that Œ¶ and gŒºŒΩ can evolve independently cannot belong to any self-consistent causal field theory. The system stabilizes on: Œ¶ determines gŒºŒΩ via equation (2.3.1); gŒºŒΩ shapes Œ¶ via equation (2.1) as an irreducible closed loop. This is the minimal structure for emergent spacetime. Geometry is not a stage on which fields perform‚Äîit is the crystallized memory of the field‚Äôs own causal history. The feedback is ontologically necessary.

2.4 Energy‚ÄìMomentum and Conservation

2.4.1 Noether Current

Under infinitesimal symmetry Œ¶ ‚Üí Œ¶+Œµ, Noether‚Äôs theorem yields a conserved fractional current J(Œ≥)Œº=‚àÇLŒ≥/‚àÇ(DŒºŒ≥Œ¶) DtŒ≥Œ¶‚àígŒºŒΩLŒ≥, DŒºŒ≥J(Œ≥)Œº=0. This defines causal energy flow, generalizing standard energy‚Äìmomentum conservation to memory-dependent systems.

2.4.2 Fractional Stress‚ÄìEnergy Tensor

The energy density and flux are T(Œ≥)00=1/2 |DtŒ≥Œ¶|2+1/2 c2|‚àáŒ≥Œ¶|2+V(Œ¶), T(Œ≥)0i=‚Ñú(DtŒ≥Œ¶DiŒ≥Œ¶‚àó). Conservation law: DtŒ≥T(Œ≥)00+‚àáŒ≥ ‚ãÖT(Œ≥)0i=0. Hence even in fractional dynamics, total causal energy is constant‚Äîits flow merely acquires temporal depth.

2.4.3 Information Flow

Define informational density œÅI=|DtŒ≥Œ¶|2, and causal information flux J‚ÉóI=‚Ñú(Œ¶‚àó‚àáŒ≥Œ¶). Then DtŒ≥œÅI+‚àáŒ≥ ‚ãÖJ‚ÉóI=0. Thus, information is conserved alongside energy, implying that information flow can be modeled as a physical fluid within the causal manifold.

Part II ‚Äî Non-Linear Feedback, Perturbation Theory, and Causal Irreversibility

2.5 Non-Linear Perturbation and Self-Interaction

Let the causal field depart slightly from the neutral potential, Œ¶=Œ¶0+Œ¥Œ¶, V(Œ¶)=1/2 m2|Œ¶|2+Œª/4 |Œ¶|4.

2.5.1 Second-Order Expansion

Substitute into the fractional field equation (2.1): Dt2Œ≥Œ¥Œ¶‚àíc2‚àá2Œ≥Œ¥Œ¶+m2Œ¥Œ¶+Œª|Œ¥Œ¶|2Œ¥Œ¶=0. (2.3) The cubic term introduces self-interaction: regions of high causal density alter their own propagation rate, creating feedback loops in both amplitude and phase.

2.5.2 Causal Perturbation Series

We expand Œ¶ in orders of the coupling Œª: Œ¶=‚àën=0‚àû ŒªnŒ¶(n). At each order n, Dt2Œ≥Œ¶(n)‚àíc2‚àá2Œ≥Œ¶(n)+m2Œ¶(n)=S(n)[Œ¶(0),‚Ä¶,Œ¶(n‚àí1)], where S(n) encodes all lower-order feedback terms. The recursive structure defines a causal Green-function hierarchy, solvable numerically or by asymptotic expansion.

2.5.3 Physical Consequences

  1. Amplitude Stabilization ‚Äì nonlinear feedback prevents runaway growth, yielding soliton-like steady states. These stable configurations serve as emergent ‚Äòidentity instances‚Äô, defined and constrained by the non-personal relational law-space of the ‚Äòidentity kernel‚Äô established in Paper 01. It is important to acknowledge that these emergent identity instances are finite and subject to dissolvability, their persistence being entirely dependent on ongoing DFVM dynamics and MSC cohesion.
  2. Energy Localization ‚Äì regions of constructive causal interference behave as particles.
  3. Phase Memory ‚Äì each perturbation retains a record of its past configuration, enabling long-range coherence.

2.6 Causal Irreversibility and the Arrow of Time

Fractional derivatives inherently break temporal symmetry when Œ≥<1.

2.6.1 Entropy Production Rate

Define causal entropy density SC=‚àíkB Œ¶‚àóln|Œ¶|2. Differentiating with respect to fractional time yields DtŒ≥SC=‚àí2kB‚Ñú (DtŒ≥Œ¶/Œ¶), which is non-zero whenever Œ≥<1. Hence, incomplete memory implies finite entropy production‚Äîmacroscopic irreversibility as a geometric property.

2.6.2 The Neutral Potential Feedback Loop

Causal self-interaction evolves toward equilibrium Œ¶‚ÜíŒ¶0, but never exactly reaches it; residual curvature maintains non-zero DtŒ≥SC. The system‚Äôs dynamics result in a continuous, partial loss of memory, which allows for ongoing evolution. This establishes the dynamical basis for time‚Äôs arrow without appealing to statistical probability.

2.6.3 Irreversibility as Information Diffusion

Expressed as continuity of information flux: DtŒ≥œÅI+‚àáŒ≥ ‚ãÖJI=‚àíœÉI, with œÉI>0 representing irreversible information diffusion. In a perfectly causal (Œ≥ = 1) regime, œÉI=0; the system is time-symmetric. In real domains, 0.8<Œ≥<1, yielding finite but bounded irreversibility.

2.7 Emergent Structure and Field Quantization

2.7.1 Standing Causal Modes

For periodic boundary conditions, Œ¶(x,t)=‚àëk AkEŒ≥(‚àíœâk2t2Œ≥)eikx, where EŒ≥ is the Mittag‚ÄìLeffler function. Modes decay algebraically rather than exponentially, giving the field a persistent memory spectrum.

2.7.2 Fractional Quantization

Quantize by promoting Œ¶,Œ¶‚àó to operators obeying [Œ¶(x),DtŒ≥Œ¶‚àó(x‚Ä≤)]=i‚ÑèŒ≥Œ¥(x‚àíx‚Ä≤), where ‚ÑèŒ≥=‚Ñè Œì(1‚àíŒ≥)‚àí1. Planck‚Äôs constant thus scales with memory depth: older memory, finer resolution. Quantum uncertainty becomes a memory-uncertainty relation.

2.7.3 Physical Implications

  • At Planck scale: Œ≥ ‚âà 0.8 ‚Üí enhanced quantum fluctuations.
  • At macroscopic scale: Œ≥ ‚Üí 1 ‚Üí classical determinism.
  • At cognitive scale: Œ≥ ‚âà 0.94 ‚Üí maximum entropy efficiency (bridge to Paper 18).

2.8 Synthesis and Transition to Paper 03

We can now state the first law of causal dynamics: Dt2Œ≥Œ¶‚àíc2‚àá2Œ≥Œ¶+V‚Ä≤(Œ¶)=0, with DtŒ≥SC‚â•0. That is, Motion is a consequence of the memory structure of the field, and the degree of forgetting defines time‚Äôs arrow.
